chapter.title: Operating storage pools using iSCSI
chapter.para: iSCSI is a standard for connecting SCSI storage devices via a TCP-based network connection. iSCSI makes it possible to use a wide range of professional storage solutions for the storage of virtual machines. This documentation describes the connection of an iSCSI storage device (also known as a target) as a storage pool for the &ucsUVMM;.

listitem.simpara: The open-iscsi package must be installed on the virtualization servers.

The iSCSI storage device must be configured in such a way that the virtualization servers can access it: The servers use the name stored in the /etc/iscsi/initiatorname.iscsi file as the initiator name. The name may still need to be generated automatically, which can be done by running /etc/init.d/open-iscsi restart once.
The libvirt interface used by UVMM does not currently support any authentication. If CHAP is used, the /etc/iscsi/iscsid.conf file must be adjusted by hand.

section.title: Integration of iSCSI storage pools
section.para: UVMM does not yet support the creation of storage pools via the UMC. The creation of storage pools is described below.

To make an additional storage pool available on a virtualization server, it is necessary to create an XML file with a description. The creation of storage pools is documented in the virtualization chapter of the UCS manual. Below, a storage pool is defined which accesses an iSCSI storage device.

listitem.simpara: The type attribute must be set to the iscsi value in the pool element.
A source element is used to specify the source servers (iSCSI target).
The target element is used to define the path to the device files. The /dev/disk/by-path should be used there for stable names.

section.para:
In the following example, a storage pool is defined, which mounts the iqn.2010-08.local.ucs:sdb iSCSI target from the xen6.ucs.local server:
<pool type='iscsi'> <name>iscsi</name> <source> <host name='xen6.ucs.local' port='3260'/> <device path='iqn.2010-08.local.ucs:sdb'/> </source> <target> <path>/dev/disk/by-path</path> </target> </pool>

This description must firstly be saved in a file (for example, in the iscsi-pool.xml file). For it to be possible to use this storage pool, the following commands must be run:
virsh pool-define iscsi-pool.xml virsh pool-start iscsi virsh pool-autostart iscsi
The UVMM service will detect the new storage pool automatically after a certain period of time. Alternatively, the service can also be restarted once so that this new storage pool information is detected immediately:
/etc/init.d/univention-virtual-machine-manager-daemon restart

section.title: Use of iSCSI storage pools
section.para: Hard disks in UVMM can then be used from the storage pool. When doing so, ensure that no new images are saved in an iSCSI storage pool and only existing ones are selected. The individual LUNs are offered as possible images.

If new iSCSI LUNs are set up, the iSCSI storage pool must still be reimported manually at present. This can be done using the following command:
virsh pool-refresh "$pool_name"
For the example above:
virsh pool-refresh iscsi

chapter.title: Xen deprecated in UCS-4
chapter.para: For UCS-4.0 Univention decided to drop support for the Xen hypervisor in favour of QEMU/KVM. UCS-4 no longer contains the package xen-4.1 as previously provided by Univention, but only the package xen as maintained by Debian.

Managing Xen virtual machines in no longer possible using &ucsUVMM; from UCS-4. Customers using Xen can continue using existing UCS-3 virtualization servers with an UCS-3 &ucsUVMM;, but should consider one of the following options longterm:

listitem.simpara: switch to the Hypervisor QEMU/KVM, which requires updating all virtual machines.
switch to the Debian based Xen.

chapter.para: Univention recommends to switch to KVM.

section.title: Switch to QEMU/KVM
section.para: When switching from Xen to KVM the drivers for para-virtual block and network devices must be changed. This switch is easier for Linux based virtual machines, as the Linux kernel already contains drivers for both hypervisors and automatically uses the right one. For Microsoft Windows bases systems the GPLPV drivers must be un-installed and replaced by the KVM-VirtIO drivers.

Univention recommends to setup a new server using KVM and to copy over the exiting image files to the new server. This has the advantage that the new setup can be tested thoroughly and a fall-back to the old hypervisor using Xen is possible.

procedure.title: Convert virtual machines from Xen to KVM

step.para: Backup all disk images of the virtual machine. The exact file path can be queried from &ucsUVMM; or by running the command virsh domblklist "$VM", where $VM is the name or UUID of one virtual machine.
Create a backup of the XML definition of the virtual machine using the command virsh dumpxml "$VM".
Prepare the virtual machine for migration by performing the following actions inside the running virtual machine:
For a Linux based virtual machine perform the following steps:

Convert any reference to Xen specific block devices like /dev/xvda1 in /etc/fstab. Use a device name independent format like LABEL= or UUID= as this is the most reliable format. The use of fixed names like /dev/vda1 should be avoided as the order of the devices might change between reboots.
The device name for CD-ROMs with QEMU/KVM is /dev/sr0 or also /dev/vdb, depending on the exact setup of the virtual machine.

Make sure GRUB is installed in the directory /boot/ and in the master boot record (MBR) of the first hard disk. You can use commands like fdisk /dev/xvda for MBR or gdisk /dev/xdva for GPT based disks to check the partition layout. Use grub-install /dev/xdva to install the boot loader into the MBR.

Run update-grub to create an up-to-date file /boot/grub/grub.cfg. Check that file and modify it using your preferred editor if Xen specific block device are used. Perform the same change as described in the first step.

Check the file /etc/inittab for any getty running on hvc0 or any other Xen specific console. Either remove those lines or convert them to a traditional serial console ttyS0, which is supported by QEMU/KVM.
Check all &ucsUCRV;s still referencing Xen specific devices and convert them to the appropriate equivalent:
Check the &ucsUCRV; kernel/modules for any Xen specific modules and remove them. The variable is a list of semicolon separated values.

On Windows the GPLPV drivers for Xen must be replaced by the VirtIO drivers for QEMU/KVM. The old drivers must be removed completely, otherwise Windows will crash. The procedure is described in WIKI: Installing signed GPLPV drivers

After a reboot the new VirtIO drivers can be installed. They are provided by the package univention-kvm-virtio and are available as an ISO image in /var/lib/livirt/images/. The exact procedure differs between Windows versions and is beyond the scope of this documentation.
Shut down the virtual machine cleanly. Suspending the machine is not enough!

The image format for storing the virtual machine data can be changes now. Xen only supports raw images, while QEMU/KVM supports more advanced formats like qcow2, which support snapshots. If you plan to use those features, it's a good time to do the conversion now using qemu-img convert -f raw -O qcow2 input.raw output.qcow2. The conversation can also be done at any later time using the same command.
Remember to change the format from raw to qcow2 in the domain definition as well.

section.para: After this the virtual machine can be migrated to KVM. There are two alternatives:

listitem.para: The recommended upgrade path is to setup a new server using KVM. This has the advantage that the old server is still available if anything goes wrong and the migration is aborted.
If you are using a shared storage, make sure that you have a backup and that you are using the correct image. If you don't have a shared storage, copy the image file to the new server.
Otherwise the virtualization server must be upgraded in-place.

warning.para: This is a one-way upgrade path. If anything goes wrong, the server has to be restored from backup!

procedure.title: Migrate server from Xen to KVM in-place

step.para: Shut down all virtual machines running on this server.
Uninstall the App Xen virtualization server.
Run the un-join scripts. Go to the &ucsUMC; UMC and opening the Join module. Click the button to run all pending join scripts.
Perform the update to UCS-4.
Install the App KVM virtualization server.
Reboot the server. This removed the Xen hypervisor below the currently running kernel and also loads the updated kernel from UCS-4.

section.para: Now the virtual machines must be re-defined. Depending on the number of virtual machines you need to migrate there are to alternatives:

listitem.para: If only a few virtual machines need migration, it's easier create new virtual machines, which re-use the old images.

procedure.title: Re-define virtual machines only re-using images

step.para: Go to the &ucsUMC; UMC and opening the &ucsUVMM; module.
Create a new virtual machine using the right profile.
When asked for the disk images, select Choose existing image as Drive type and select the existing image from the corresponding storage pool.
Repeat this step for all drives.
Pay special attention to the Image format if you performed the conversion from raw to qcow2 mentioned above.
Finish creating the machine but do not start it yet.

Re-open the virtual machine and go to the Devices tab. Open all network interfaces and change the MAC address back to the original one, which you can get from the XML definition file. Otherwise the operating system will detect the change as a new network device and will require further manual updates like deleting /etc/udev/rules/70-persistent-net.rules.
Also verify that the Source setting matches the name of your bridge interface, as this might have changed from eth0 to br0. See for more details.
Save the modification.

listitem.para: If many virtual machines need updating, the XML definition from Xen can be semi-automatically transformed into a XML definition for KVM.

procedure.title: Re-define virtual machines convetting the Xen XML definition

step.para: Use the command virsh dumpxml "$VM" to generate the XML file describing a single virtual machine on the Xen host.
Modify the XML file as follows:
Change the attribute /domain/@type from xen to kvm.
QEMU/KVM only supports full-virtualization (HVM).
Set the element /domain/os/type to hvm.
Remove the elements /domain/bootloader and /domain/bootloader_args.
Remove the element /domain/os/loader for HVM domains.
The element /domain/devices/emulator should point to /usr/bin/kvm.
Update each block device /domain/devices/disk:
In the element driver change the following attributes:
Change @type='tap2' to qemu.
Change @name='aio' to raw or qcow2 if you converted the image file as mentioned above.
In the element target change the following attributes:
Replace any @bus='xen' with virtio and convert the attribute @dev from xvdX to vdX.
You can also use @bus='ide' and @dev='hdX' if an emulated IDE device is preferred to the more efficient VirtIO.
Update each network interface /domain/devices/interfaces:
Change model/@type to virtio or any other type supported by QEMU/KVM like e1000 or rtl8139.
Remove any element /domain/devices/interfaces/script.
Check that the attribute source/@bridge references a valid bridge interface on the target host system. See for more details.
In any element /domain/devices/console/target changed the attribute from @type='xen' to @type='serial'.
In any element /domain/devices/input change the attribute from @bus='xen' to @bus='usb'.
On the target host define the virtual machine using virsh define "$VM.xml" where $VM.xml is the name of the XML file.

section.title: Switch to Debian-Xen
section.para: The major differences between the UCS version and Debian version are:

listitem.simpara: Support for Xen was removed from UVMM. Virtual machines can not be managed using UVMM.
The UCS version contained several patches on top of the Debian version, which fixed several issues (Bug 18357, Bug 23394, Bug 23812, Bug 36098). Their status in Debian is unknown.
The UCS version of libvirt contained several patches specifically for Xen, which are no longer applied (Bug 20024, Bug 29532).

The UCS Linux kernel contained the module blktap built-in, which was used to provide block devices for virtual machines. This module is no longer included in the default kernel, but can be self-compiled using DKMS and the package blktap-dkms.
UCS used a custom network script to setup bridging. They are not used by Debian. As such bridging must be setup manually. See and the chapter on configuring bridges in the .

UCS-3 had its own source code package for Xen, which was used to build several binary packages. This might break an automatic update, as files might be moved between packages. The package manager dpkg will then refuse to install the Debian packages. As such it is advisable to remove the old UCS packages before installing the new Debian based packages.

section.para: The following commands can be used as a start to migrate to the Debian version of Xen. After that many more things might need manual changes.

warning.para: This is a one-way upgrade path. Backup the host and test the procedure in isolation before doing this on a production system!

section.programlisting: # Remove xen-4.1 before update apt-get remove xen-4.1 libxenstore3.0 libxen4.1 libxen-dev xen-4.1-dbg # Upgrade to UCS-4 univention-upgrade # Re-install xen ucr set repository/online/unmaintained=yes univention-install xen

chapter.title: Network setup for virtual machines
chapter.para: With UCS-3 a script renamed the physical interface ethX into pethX and created a bridge interface with the old name as a replacement. This is no longer recommended as this script only supports a very basic setup and is confusing to most users. As such UCS was changed to support bridging, bonding and VLANs, which is described fully in the UCS manual.

Unfortunately this leads to a user visible change of the network interface, as ethX now no longer is the name of the bridge interface but of the physical interface again. As this interface name is referenced in the domain configurations of all existing virtual machines, they will no longer start. This is further complicated by the fact, that each snapshot and saved virtual machine also contains the old information, which should be updated.

procedure.title: Convert virtual machines to new network bridge setup

step.para: Repeat the following steps on each host and for each virtual machine to be updated. Use the command virsh list --all to get a list of all defined domains.
For each virtual machine named $vm update the persistent domain configuration using the following steps:
Run the command virsh edit "$vm" to get the configuration opened in an editor.
In the XML file lookup all network interfaces below /domain/devices/interfaces/source and change the attribute bridge from eth0 to br0 (or whatever).
Quit the editor to save the file.
If the virtual machine has snapshots, they need to be updated as well. Use the command virsh snapshot-list "$vm" to get a list of all snapshots.
For each snapshot named $snap update the domain configuration of that snapshot using the following steps:
Run the command virsh snapshot-edit "$vm" "$snap" to get the configuration opened in an editor.
In the XML file lookup all network interfaces below /domainsnapshot/domain/devices/interfaces/source and change the attribute bridge from eth0 to br0 (or whatever).
Quit the editor to save the file.

If the domain is suspend to disk, the suspend image also contains a copy of the domain configuration. Use the command virsh dominfo "$vm" to check Managed save. If it is yes, the image must be either updates or discarded.

Run the command virsh managedsave-remove "$vm" to discard the saved data. This will remove the runtime state of the virtual machine, but the persistent date stored in the image files is not discarded. Normally the operating system will then perform a file system check as it looks like the virtual machine has crashed
To update the image, run the following sequence of commands command virsh save-image-edit "/var/lib/libvirt/qemu/save/$vm.save".

section.title: Migrating virtual machines between hosts
section.para: (Live-)migration also transfers the domain configuration. This breaks when the network interface names differ between the source and destination host. Because of that it is strongly advised to shut down any virtual machine cleanly and to transfer them as described above.

There is a second option available which allows updating virtual machines while they are migrated from a UCS-3 to a UCS-4 host. libvirt provides a hook mechanism, which can be used to rewrite the virtual machine configuration on-the-fly for incoming migrations. This is fully described in the libvirt hook documentation.

As UCS-4 is using a newer version of libvirt, additional settings are added to the virtual machine configuration, which older versions can't process. Make sure to backup the pre-migration configuration using virsh dumpxml "$vm".

section.title: UVMM profiles
section.para: In addition to that the UVMM profiles should be updated as well, as they name the network interface which is used to connect newly created virtual machines. This is described in the in UVMM chapter in the section Changing default network.
